title: Investigative task - pill and injection treatments

content.question: Directions: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be graded on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy of your results and explanation. Two treatments, A and B, showed promise for treating a potentially fatal disease. A randomized experiment was conducted to determine whether there is a significant difference in the survival rate between patients who receive treatment A and those who receive treatment B. Of 154 patients who received treatment A, 38 survived for at least 15 years, whereas 16 of the 164 patients who received treatment B survived at least 15 years. Treatment A can be administered only as a pill, and treatment B can be administered only as an injection. Can this randomized experiment be performed as a double-blind experiment? Why or why not? The conditions for inference have been met. Construct and interpret a 95 percent confidence interval for the difference between the proportion of the population who would survive at least 15 years if given treatment A and the proportion of the population who would survive at least 15 years if given treatment B. In many of these types of studies, physicians are interested in the ratio of survival probabilities, <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mfrac> <mrow> <msub> <mi>p</mi> <mi>A</mi> </msub> </mrow> <mrow> <msub> <mi>p</mi> <mi>B</mi> </msub> </mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3A88@</annotation> </semantics> </math>, where pA represents the true 15-year survival rate for all patients who receive treatment A and pB represents the true 15-year survival rate for all patients who receive treatment B. This ratio is usually referred to as the relative risk of the two treatments. For example, a relative risk of 1 indicates the survival rates for patients receiving the two treatments are equal, whereas a relative risk of 1.5 indicates that the survival rate for patients receiving treatment A is 50 percent higher than the survival rate for patients receiving treatment B. An estimator of the relative risk is the ratio of estimated probabilities,<math> <semantics> <mrow> <mfrac> <mrow> <msub> <mover accent="true"> <mi>p</mi> <mo>^</mo> </mover> <mi>A</mi> </msub> </mrow> <mrow> <msub> <mover accent="true"> <mi>p</mi> <mo>^</mo> </mover> <mi>B</mi> </msub> </mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3AA8@</annotation> </semantics> </math> c. Using the data from the randomized experiment described above, compute the estimate of the relative risk. The sampling distribution of <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mfrac> <mrow> <msub> <mover accent="true"> <mi>p</mi> <mo>^</mo> </mover> <mi>A</mi> </msub> </mrow> <mrow> <msub> <mover accent="true"> <mi>p</mi> <mo>^</mo> </mover> <mi>B</mi> </msub> </mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3AA8@</annotation> </semantics> </math> is skewed. However, when both sample sizes nA and nV are relatively large, the distribution of <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>ln</mi> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mfrac> <mrow> <msub> <mover accent="true"> <mi>p</mi> <mo>^</mo> </mover> <mi>A</mi> </msub> </mrow> <mrow> <msub> <mover accent="true"> <mi>p</mi> <mo>^</mo> </mover> <mi>B</mi> </msub> </mrow> </mfrac> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3DFF@</annotation> </semantics> </math> —the natural logarithm of relative risk—is approximately normal with a mean of <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>ln</mi> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mfrac> <mrow> <msub> <mi>p</mi> <mi>A</mi> </msub> </mrow> <mrow> <msub> <mi>p</mi> <mi>B</mi> </msub> </mrow> </mfrac> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3DDF@</annotation> </semantics> </math> and a standard deviation of <math> <semantics> <msqrt> <mrow> <mfrac> <mrow> <mn>1</mn> <mo>−</mo> <msub> <mi>p</mi> <mi>A</mi> </msub> </mrow> <mrow> <msub> <mi>n</mi> <mi>A</mi> </msub> <mtext> </mtext> <msub> <mi>p</mi> <mi>A</mi> </msub> </mrow> </mfrac> <mo>+</mo> <mfrac> <mrow> <mn>1</mn> <mo>−</mo> <msub> <mi>p</mi> <mi>B</mi> </msub> </mrow> <mrow> <msub> <mi>n</mi> <mi>B</mi> </msub> <mtext> </mtext> <msub> <mi>p</mi> <mi>B</mi> </msub> </mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> </msqrt> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4AFC@</annotation> </semantics> </math>, where pA and pB can be estimated by using p̂A and p̂B . When a 95 percent confidence interval for <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>ln</mi> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mfrac> <mrow> <msub> <mi>p</mi> <mi>A</mi> </msub> </mrow> <mrow> <msub> <mi>p</mi> <mi>B</mi> </msub> </mrow> </mfrac> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3DDF@</annotation> </semantics> </math> is known, an approximate 95 precent confidence interval for <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mfrac> <mrow> <msub> <mi>p</mi> <mi>A</mi> </msub> </mrow> <mrow> <msub> <mi>p</mi> <mi>B</mi> </msub> </mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3A88@</annotation> </semantics> </math> —the relative risk of the two treatments—can be constructed by applying the inverse of the natural logarithm to the endpoints of the confidence interval for <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>ln</mi> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mfrac> <mrow> <msub> <mi>p</mi> <mi>A</mi> </msub> </mrow> <mrow> <msub> <mi>p</mi> <mi>B</mi> </msub> </mrow> </mfrac> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3DDF@</annotation> </semantics> </math>. d. The conditions for inference are met for the data in the experiment above, and a 95 percent confidence interval for <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>ln</mi> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mfrac> <mrow> <msub> <mi>p</mi> <mi>A</mi> </msub> </mrow> <mrow> <msub> <mi>p</mi> <mi>B</mi> </msub> </mrow> </mfrac> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3DDF@</annotation> </semantics> </math> is (0.3868, 1.4690). Construct and interpret a 95 percent confidence interval for the relative risk, <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mfrac> <mrow> <msub> <mi>p</mi> <mi>A</mi> </msub> </mrow> <mrow> <msub> <mi>p</mi> <mi>B</mi> </msub> </mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3A88@</annotation> </semantics> </math> , of the two treatments. e. What is an advantage of using the interval in part (d) over using the interval in part (b) ?

frqParts.text: Directions: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be graded on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy of your results and explanation. Two treatments, A and B, showed promise for treating a potentially fatal disease. A randomized experiment was conducted to determine whether there is a significant difference in the survival rate between patients who receive treatment A and those who receive treatment B. Of 154 patients who received treatment A, 38 survived for at least 15 years, whereas 16 of the 164 patients who received treatment B survived at least 15 years. However, when both sample sizes nA and nV are relatively large, the distribution of <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>ln</mi> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mfrac> <mrow> <msub> <mover accent="true"> <mi>p</mi> <mo>^</mo> </mover> <mi>A</mi> </msub> </mrow> <mrow> <msub> <mover accent="true"> <mi>p</mi> <mo>^</mo> </mover> <mi>B</mi> </msub> </mrow> </mfrac> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3DFF@</annotation> </semantics> </math> —the natural logarithm of relative risk—is approximately normal with a mean of <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>ln</mi> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mfrac> <mrow> <msub> <mi>p</mi> <mi>A</mi> </msub> </mrow> <mrow> <msub> <mi>p</mi> <mi>B</mi> </msub> </mrow> </mfrac> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3DDF@</annotation> </semantics> </math> and a standard deviation of <math> <semantics> <msqrt> <mrow> <mfrac> <mrow> <mn>1</mn> <mo>−</mo> <msub> <mi>p</mi> <mi>A</mi> </msub> </mrow> <mrow> <msub> <mi>n</mi> <mi>A</mi> </msub> <mtext> </mtext> <msub> <mi>p</mi> <mi>A</mi> </msub> </mrow> </mfrac> <mo>+</mo> <mfrac> <mrow> <mn>1</mn> <mo>−</mo> <msub> <mi>p</mi> <mi>B</mi> </msub> </mrow> <mrow> <msub> <mi>n</mi> <mi>B</mi> </msub> <mtext> </mtext> <msub> <mi>p</mi> <mi>B</mi> </msub> </mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> </msqrt> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4AFC@</annotation> </semantics> </math>, where pA and pB can be estimated by using p̂A and p̂B . skill.text: Skill 1.C: Describe an appropriate method for gathering and representing data.
